citation.article-title: Micromonospora rosaria sp. nov., nom. rev., the rosaramicin producer.

p.s: Description of Micromonospora rosaria sp. nov., nom. rev. (ex Wagman, Waitz, Marquez, Murawski, Oden, Testa, and Weinstein, 1972)
The specific epithet refers to the wine red diffusible pigment formed by strain NRRL 3718T.
The vegetative hyphae are branched and approximately 0.5 μm in diameter.
Spores that are 1.5 to 1.8 μm in diameter occur along the length of the hyphae, are borne singly, and are either sessile or on short sporophores.
Growth and sporulatioh is of the open web type of Luedemann (13) (Fig. 1).

Electron microscopic analysis of spores reveals the presence of warts which arise from the outer portion of the spore wall (Fig. 2), as described by Luedemann and Casmer for Micromonospora chalcea spores (16).
The strains grow well on most of the rich organic media tested (Table 2).
Poor growth occurs on calcium malate, calcium citrate, and peptone-glucose agar media.

Strains grow in the presence of gentamicin, sisomicin, erythromycin, rosaramicin, everninomicin, novobiocin, clindamycin, lincomycin, cycloserine, penicillin G, and cephalothin at concentrations of 50 μg/ml but do not grow in the presence of neomycin, kanamycin, streptomycin, tetracycline, or rifamycin at concentrations of 50 μg/ml.
Growth occurs in the presence of 3% NaCl and in the presence of Na2S203 at a concentration of 4%.
No growth occurs in the presence of lysozyme or salicylate.
Strains are sensitive to acid, as determined by lack of growth on potato slices (12).
Growth on ATCC medium 172 (1) agar slants is most abundant at 35 and 40°C and is poor at 42°C.
No growth occurs at 10 and 45°C.
Vegetative mycelial pigments range from orangish brown to purplish black.
A characteristic wine red diffusible pigment is formed on most media, as is a grayish white bloom of short, sterile aerial mycelia (13).
Hydrolyzed whole cells contain both hydroxy (20) and meso-diaminopimelic acids as characteristic amino acids.
Arabinose and xylose are the characteristic sugars.
Galactose is also present.

D- and L-arabinose, fructose, methyl-α-D-glucopyranoside, methyl-β-D-glucopyranoside, D-glucose, lactose, maltose, D-mannose, D-mannitol, L-rhamnose, D-ribose , sucrose, D-trehalose, and D-xylose are utilized with the formation of wine red to reddish brown diffusible pigments.

The pigment interferes in the Gordon acid production test for carbon utilization (6), turning the yellow positive reaction back to a color similar to the color of the original purple indicator, making readings impossible.
Adonitol, dulcitol, erythritol, glycerol, D-melibiose, D-melezitose, and D-raffinose are not utilized.
D-Galactose utilization is weak.
Of the organic acids tested, acetate, gluconate, glutamate, propionate, and pyruvate are utilized; benzoate, citrate, lactate, malate, oleate, oxalate, succinate, and tartrate are not utilized.
Tyrosine, xylan, chitin, casein, starch, gelatin, esculin, and arbutin are hydrolyzed; hypoxanthine, xanthine, and hippurate are not hydrolyzed.
The breakdown of Dorset egg medium and Loeffer serum medium is weak.
Urease is formed.
Nitrate reductase is negative.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of strain NRRL 3718TM deoxyribonucleic acid is 75 mol% (T.
R.
Monahan, M.S. thesis, Seton Hall University, South Orange, N.J., 1976).
M . rosaria strain NRRL 3718 (= ATCC 29337) is designated the type strain of the species.
